name: Golden Pheasant
description: One of the most colorful pheasant species. The male has a striking golden crest, a red underbody, and long tail feathers. The female is a subdued brownish color.
proportions: Body length from 61 cm (female) to 115 cm (male), with the tail up to 79 cm; weight 550–875 g
reproduction: Females lay 5–12 eggs and incubate them for 22 days.
attractions: Despite the male's vibrant coloration, it escapes notice in the wild by staying in dark juniper thickets, blending with the shadows, so little is known about its wild life. Like all pheasants, it forages on the ground, digging with its strong beak. At night, it roosts in tree canopies. It flies sharply and quickly but prefers to flee and hide in vegetation when threatened.
breeding: The first golden pheasants arrived in 1999. We currently keep a pair that came from Plzeň Zoo in 2013.
